books.title: The Catcher in the Rye
books.author: J.D. Salinger
books.description: The Catcher in the Rye is a novel by J.D. Salinger, published in 1951. It is known for its themes of teenage angst and alienation. The protagonist, Holden Caulfield, is a cynical teenager who wanders through New York City after being expelled from an elite boarding school.

books.title: To Kill a Mockingbird
books.author: Harper Lee
books.description: To Kill a Mockingbird is a novel by Harper Lee published in 1960. It was immediately successful, winning the Pulitzer Prize, and has become a classic of modern American literature.

books.title: The Hobbit
books.author: J.R.R. Tolkien
books.description: The Hobbit, or There and Back Again, is a fantasy novel by J.R.R. Tolkien, published in 1937. It is a prelude to Tolkien's later and more complex work, The Lord of the Rings.

books.author: George Orwell
books.description: 1984 is a dystopian novel by George Orwell published in 1949. The story takes place in an imagined future, the year 1984, when much of the world has fallen victim to perpetual war, omnipresent government surveillance, and propaganda.

books.title: Pride and Prejudice
books.author: Jane Austen
books.description: Pride and Prejudice is a romantic novel by Jane Austen, first published in 1813. The story charts the emotional development of the protagonist, Elizabeth Bennet, who learns the error of making hasty judgments and comes to appreciate the difference between the superficial and the essential.

books.title: The Great Gatsby
books.author: F. Scott Fitzgerald
books.description: The Great Gatsby is a novel written by American author F. Scott Fitzgerald that follows a cast of characters living in the fictional towns of West Egg and East Egg on prosperous Long Island in the summer of 1922.

books.title: Moby-Dick
books.author: Herman Melville
books.description: Moby-Dick; or, The Whale is an 1851 novel by American writer Herman Melville. The book is the sailor Ishmael's narrative of the obsessive quest of Ahab, captain of the whaling ship Pequod, for revenge on a giant white sperm whale, Moby Dick, who had bitten off Ahab's leg at the knee during a previous voyage.

books.title: Brave New World
books.author: Aldous Huxley
books.description: Brave New World is a dystopian novel by English author Aldous Huxley, written in 1931 and published in 1932. Largely set in a futuristic World State, whose citizens are environmentally engineered into an intelligence-based social hierarchy, the novel anticipates developments in reproductive technology, sleep-learning, psychological manipulation, and classical conditioning.

books.title: The Lord of the Rings
books.author: J.R.R. Tolkien
books.description: The Lord of the Rings is an epic high-fantasy novel written by English author and scholar J.R.R. Tolkien. The story began as a sequel to Tolkien's 1937 fantasy novel The Hobbit, but it grew into a much larger work. It was written in stages between 1937 and 1949, much of it during World War II.

books.title: The Chronicles of Narnia
books.author: C.S. Lewis
books.description: The Chronicles of Narnia is a series of seven fantasy novels by C.S. Lewis. It is considered a classic of children's literature and is the author's best-known work, having sold over 100 million copies in 47 languages.

books.title: Crime and Punishment
books.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
books.description: Crime and Punishment is a novel by the Russian author Fyodor Dostoevsky. It was first published in the literary journal The Russian Messenger in twelve monthly installments during 1866. It is the second of Dostoevsky's full-length novels following his return from ten years of exile in Siberia.

books.title: One Hundred Years of Solitude
books.author: Gabriel García Márquez
books.description: One Hundred Years of Solitude is a landmark 1967 novel by Colombian author Gabriel García Márquez. It tells the multi-generational story of the Buendía family in the fictional town of Macondo.

books.title: The Road
books.author: Cormac McCarthy
books.description: The Road is a post-apocalyptic novel by American writer Cormac McCarthy. It tells the story of a father and his young son, journeying through a post-apocalyptic world. The novel was awarded the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction in 2007.

books.title: Anna Karenina
books.author: Leo Tolstoy
books.description: Anna Karenina is a novel by the Russian author Leo Tolstoy, first published from 1873 to 1877. The novel tells the tragic story of a married aristocrat and her affair with the affluent Count Vronsky.

books.title: The Odyssey
books.author: Homer
books.description: The Odyssey is one of two major ancient Greek epic poems attributed to Homer. It is, in part, a sequel to the Iliad, the other Homeric epic. The Odyssey is a fundamental work in the modern Western canon, being the oldest extant piece of Western literature, and a foundational work for Western literature in general.

books.title: Wuthering Heights
books.author: Emily Brontë
books.description: Wuthering Heights is a novel by Emily Brontë, published in 1847 under her pseudonym Ellis Bell. It is her only finished novel. Wuthering Heights and Anne Brontë's Agnes Grey were accepted by publisher Thomas Newby before the success of her sister Charlotte's novel Jane Eyre.

books.title: Frankenstein
books.author: Mary Shelley
books.description: Frankenstein; or, The Modern Prometheus is a novel written by English author Mary Shelley, published anonymously in 1818. It tells the story of Victor Frankenstein, a young scientist who creates a sapient creature in an unorthodox scientific experiment.

books.title: The Count of Monte Cristo
books.author: Alexandre Dumas
books.description: The Count of Monte Cristo is an adventure novel by French author Alexandre Dumas, first serialized in 1844–1846. The story takes place in France, Italy, and islands in the Mediterranean during the historical events of 1815–1839.

books.title: The Iliad
books.author: Homer
books.description: The Iliad is an ancient Greek epic poem traditionally said to be the work of Homer. It is one of the oldest extant works of literature, dating to the 8th or 7th century BCE, and is in the public domain.

books.title: Sense and Sensibility
books.author: Jane Austen
books.description: Sense and Sensibility is a novel by Jane Austen, published in 1811. It was published anonymously, and the author's name was not widely known until the publication of her later novels, beginning with Emma in 1815.
